poem:
### Freshman Finance

In the echo of parents' farewells,  
the clatter of coins and clicking keys  
compose the melody of freshman fears—  
debts dancing in rented rooms.  
On a desk, atop unopened books,  
nestles the solemn whisper of adulthood—  
insurance, utilities, the TV licence:  
incantations of a new reality,  
age-old chorus sung to the tune of youth.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Do I need a TV licence? Should I insure my things? Last-minute money tips for students The new university year is about to start, and if you – or someone you know – is heading off for the first time, finances might be a big concern. Student loans only stretch so far, and this could be the first time you have had to deal with real budgeting to cover accommodation, food and other bills. To". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
